docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text:
This guide contains in depth information about the transition from Windows to Linux, specifically Linux Ubuntu.

There are many concerns with Windows and Microsoft that might make a person want to switch to on open source OS like Linux. However, there are jarring differences between the two that are essential to understand before transitioning.

You will learn the differences between Windows and Linux, as well as how to install and start using Linux as a Windows user.

docs.title: 1.1 Limitations of Windows
docs.text:
Windows is a closed source operating system developed by Microsoft. While Windows can be downloaded and used for free, any customization or personalization of the system is locked behind a $140 license. This license is also needed to recieve security updates and patches, meaning protection in windows is locked behind a pay wall.

Windows has been known for having questionable security practices. The built in anti-virus, Windows Defender, is known for not being the most effective, and security analysis recommends downloading 3rd-party anti-virus software such as MalwareBytes. Due to Windows being such a popular OS, it has been targeted with numerous cyber attacks, including WannaCry.

Being closed sourced means limited customization and transparency. Users cannot customize OS level displays like the File Explorer, while they also can't verify how Windows handles their data and privacy. In recent updates, Microsoft added Copilot Vision which allows the Copilot AI to view your screen. While this says it follows correct data collecting protocols, there is no way to properly check and confirm Windows did not take any shortcuts.

docs.title: 1.2 Benefits of Linux
docs.text:
Unlike Windows, Linux gives users a lot more freedom along with more security. Linux is open source, meaning all of the source code is available to the public. This allows many benefits for users, such as the ability to "fork" code and have people create their own version of linux more suited for certain aspects the user desires. With countless distributions, Linux offers a very customizable experience for whoever is willing to try it out.

With it being open source, it can be somewhat confusing for those just starting out, but luckily there is a very active community that loves to help others get started. If you wish to get involved in this section of linux, it is highly recommended to check out the Linux Forum, where you'll be able to ask questions and get answers from more experienced users.

Another great benefit of Linux is that it has extremely efficient performance, meaning it can run on really old or less powerful devices, making it a great choice for those with old devices looking to extend their lifespan, or simply those that want their operating system to take up less processing power. Along with efficient performance, Linux is also known for its relibility, almost never needing updates or restarts like other operating systems. Along with everything already said, one of the best benefits of Linux is that it is completely free to download and use, without the need for a paid license like windows.

docs.title: 1.3 Possible Negatives of Linux
docs.text:
Now like anything in this world, Linux isn't perfect. The main problem is that it is a fairly steep learning curve when beginning, but the great thing about that is this User Guide is going to help you out! And as aforementioned, if you have any questions that this guide does not answer feel free to post a question on this Linux Forum.

Another limitation is Linux's gaming compatibility. Most distributions are not optimized fpr games, meaning that Linux does not support a lot of games, and often runs them inneficiently when it can.

Another possible drawback is actually the amount of freedom the user has with Linux, as it can be fairly overwhelming, making them not know where to start. Yet again this is where this guide will come in handy, completely explaining the process to switch from windows to Linux, including downloading, installation, customization, and much more.

docs.title: 3. Basic Commands
docs.text: One of the biggest differences between Windows and Linux is the way in which you interact with your files. Windows relies mostly on graphical interfaces and using the file explorer to interact with the system, but Linux uses the command line/terminal for quicker control of your system. Once you have downloaded Linux Ubuntu, there are a multitude of commands that you must learn in order to operate and interact with your system.

docs.title: 3.1 Figuring out file and directory informationpwd - Print Working Directory ls - List All Files
docs.text:
This command effectively shows the path to the directory you are currently in.

Ex. - When you are in your Desktop, if you ran the pwd command, the terminal would output "/home//Desktop" This command lists all the files that are in the directory you are currently in.

Ex. - If you are in a directory named animals in your Downloads (path would be /home//Downloads/animals) that contains dog.txt, cat.txt, and bird.txt, running:

ls

lists out all of those files to the terminal.

docs.title: 3.2 Navigating directoriescd <path-to-directory> - Navigate to a directorycd .. – Go “Up” a Directory
docs.text:
This command moves you to the directory you specify.

Ex. - If you are in a the root directory and want to move down to a directory at path /animals/cats, you would run the command cd /animals/cats and you would be moved into the cats directory

This command moves you up one level in the directory structure.

Ex. – If you are in /home/<your-username>/Downloads/animals and run:

cd ..

You would move up to /home/<your-username>/Downloads

docs.title: 3.3 Altering files and directoriesmkdir <directory-name> – Make a Directoryrmdir <directory-name> – Remove a Directory <touch <filename> – Create a New File cp <source> <destination> – Copy Files or Directories mv <source> <destination> – Move or Rename Files rm <filename> – Delete a File rm -r <directory-name> - removes a directory and ALL files inside it
docs.text:
This command creates a new folder/directory in the location you are currently in.

Ex. – To create a folder named projects, type:

mkdir projects

Now a new folder named projects will appear in your current directory.

This command deletes an **empty** directory.

Ex. – If you want to delete an empty folder named old_files, type:

rmdir old_files

This command creates a new, empty file.

Ex. – To make a new text file named notes.txt, type

touch notes.txt

You can then open it later with any text editor of your choosing.

This command copies a file or folder from one location to another.

Ex. – To copy notes.txt into the Documents folder:

cp notes.txt ~/Documents

This command moves a file or renames it.

Ex. – To rename notes.txt to summary.txt:

mv notes.txt summary.txt

Or to move it into another folder:

mv summary.txt ~/Documents

Warning

  • This command permanently deletes a file, there is NO RECYCLING BIN to restore it

Ex. – To delete the file notes.txt, type:

rm notes.txt

Additionally, you can do:

If you have a directory named animals with cat.txt and dog.txt inside it, running:

rm -r animals

Will effectively remove animals along with dog.txt and cat.txt

docs.title: 4. Customization
docs.text: Customization is a huge advantage of using Linux over other operating systems. Due to the open source nature of Linux, many application developers give access to users to customize even the most low level things such as window decoration and styles.

docs.title: 4.1 Basic customization
docs.text:
Changing the theme is a great first step in making the Linux experience custom. Updating the theme includes changing the system style, accent color, and/or the background image. To update the theme:

  1. Open the Activities Overview by moving the mouse to the top left corner or by pressing the Super key

Info

Depending on specific keyboard, the Super might be different, but on most keyboards, it is mapped to the Windows key.

  1. In the text box, type "Appearance". Then select the first result.

This opens the Appearance menu in settings.

The first thing in this menu is the theme style. In this menu you can change the accent color and switch to dark theme.

Scrolling down the menu allows you to change the background image. Ubuntu comes with template backgrounds, but you can upload your own images using the + add picture button.

These are the basic appearance customizations that are built in to Ubuntu. Once you are in the settings menu, you are also able to change a couple other settings to customize Ubuntu to your liking by going to "Ubuntu Desktop".

Ubuntu Desktop menu settings: - Desktop icon size - Alignment of desktop icons - Dock size and orientation - Enabling / Disabling Tiling

These are the very basic settings that can be changed with the default Ubuntu configuration. Next we are going to explain a tool used to make some more tweaks using GNOME Tweaks program.

docs.title: 4.2 GNOME Tweaks
docs.text:
Due to the way that Ubuntu desktop is managed, we can use GNOME Tweaks to make a few more customizations.

  1. Open a terminal using the Activities Overview screen
  2. In the terminal type the following command
sudo apt install gnome-tweaks
  1. Type in password to give installation permissions

Once GNOME tweaks is installed, open the Activites Overview screen and type "Tweaks" and launch the program. This will open the following window:

On the side menu there are many different navigation menus. We have listed the most popular customizations from the menus here:

Fonts
  • Interface font type
  • Document font type
  • Monospace font type
  • Font antialiasing
  • Font scaling
Appearance
  • Cursor style
  • Icon style
  • Background image
  • Dark style background image
Sound
  • System sound themes
Windows
  • Titlebar click actions
  • Titlebar buttons
  • Click actions

There are many more customizations with GNOME Tweaks, and we highly recomend going through them all and experimenting to make Linux yours.

docs.title: 4.3 GNOME Extensions
docs.text:
Another powerful feature of GNOME being Ubuntu's desktop manager, is that it allows for extensions to be installed. These extensions can range from just adding rounded corners to redesigning the whole desktop enviornment.

To get started:

  1. Open a terminal using the Activities Overview screen
  2. In the terminal use the following command to install GNOME shell extensions
sudo apt install chrome-gnome-shell
  1. Type in your password, press enter, and wait for installation to complete
  2. Open Firefox
  3. Install the GNOME Shell Integration extension from Firefox Browser Add-Ons
  4. Browse available extensions at GNOME Extensions list

Once you select a extension to install:

  1. Click on the extension to open its page
  2. In the top right, press the Install button and confirm the permissions

Now the extension is installed. To remove an extension:

  1. Open the Activities Overview screen and search for Extensions
  2. Open the Extensions app
  3. Scroll until you find the extension to remove
  4. Press on the three dots menu, and select Remove

The extension should be removed. Now that you understand how to use the built in Ubuntu customization options as well as GNOME extensions, customize your workspace to your desire.

docs.title: 2. Installing and Booting Linux
docs.text:
This section includes a step-by-step guide on how to install Linux Ubuntu. You will learn how to flash an OS to a USB Drive, how to select a boot drive, and Linux set up instructions. Please read the warnings about installing a new OS for the first time.

Warning

  • File loss: When installing a new OS, all existing data on your computer is overwritten by the new OS. If you have any important files on your computer, be sure to back up everything on something like an external drive or the cloud.
  • App Compatibility: There are many apps compatible with Windows that aren't compatible with Linux. If there are apps that you absolutely need on Linux, be sure to research their compatibility.
  • Driver Compatibility: Linux almost always has open source drivers compatible with your hardware, but sometimes less essential hardware like certain WiFi cards or Bluetooth don't have support. Be sure to check if you're worried about more niche hardware.

docs.title: 2.1 Flashing Linux to a USB Drive
docs.text:
Make sure to have your USB drive plugged into your computer. In this section you will download Ubuntu and an OS flasher, and use the flasher to make your USB drive into an Ubuntu bootdrive.

  1. Visit https://ubuntu.com/desktop.
  2. Click Download Ubuntu Desktop in the left corner of the screen and wait for the download to complete. (you can ignore the newletter sign up)
  3. Visit https://etcher.balena.io/.
  4. Click Download Etcher in the middle of the screen and wait for the download to complete.
  5. Click on the .exe file for etcher to open the flashing application.
  6. Click the Flash from File button, and select the Ubuntu download from earlier.
  7. Click Select a Drive, and select your USB drive. Press select.
  8. Press Flash and wait for the OS to flash to your drive.

docs.title: 2.2 Selecting a Boot Drive
docs.text:
Make sure your boot drive is plugged in. In this section you will learn how to enter your computer's BIOS to select your Ubuntu bootdrive to reboot your computer in Ubuntu. - Each computer has a key that boots them into its BIOS. This key is dictated by either the brand of your computer or your motherboard manufacturer if your computer doesn't have a brand. For most computers the BIOS button is either F2, F10, esc, or delete.

  1. Shut down your computer.
  2. Power on your computer and rapidly press your BIOS key. (common BIOS keys listed above)

Info

Each computer's BIOS is different, if you are having trouble finding your boot order settings, please reference the BIOS information for your computer or motherboard's brand online.

  1. Navigate to your Boot Order configuration. (Will usually be under a tab or section titled Boot)
  2. Select your boot drive as first priority.
  3. Reboot your computer. Your boot drive's grub menu should appear.
  4. Using the arrow keys, navigate to Try or Install Ubuntu if not already selected, and press enter.
  5. Wait for Ubuntu to boot up.

docs.title: 2.2 Installer Prompts
docs.text:
Most of the installer prompts are straight forward for an experienced Windows user. In this section we will only go over installer prompts that are important or confusing, in the order they appear. All other prompts don't matter or are preference based.

  1. Connect to the internet
    • It's not necessary, but we reccomend connecting to the internet so Ubuntu can automatically install drivers for your hardware. This will save you time after the installation completes.

Warning

By selecting install Ubuntu in the next installer prompt, your Windows OS and all its files will be permanently deleted.

  1. What do you want to do with Ubuntu?
    • Ubuntu gives you the option to install or try Ubuntu. If you are unsure about Ubuntu, select Try Ubuntu and then install later when you're ready. Note that it will run slow on try Ubuntu, since the OS is operating off your boot drive rather than your computer.
  2. What apps would you like to install to start with?
    • As a Windows user, many of your essential office apps come with your installation. Because of this, we reccomend choosing Extended selection, which will install a few helpful office apps and utilities with your installation.
  3. Install reccommended proprietary software?
    • Check both of these boxes. This will install open source drivers compatible with your hardware.
  4. How do you want to install Ubuntu?
    • Select Erase disk and install Ubuntu.
  5. At the last prompt window, press Install and then in the next window Restart Now. Wait for the installation to finish and Ubuntu to boot back up.
  6. Navigate through the final installer prompts, the choices aren't important.
